_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Name:  Sysco Jackson, LLC
EPA ID:  1000 0021 5091

Sysco Jackson, LLC
Jackson, Mississippi

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
Executive Summary

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
    
At this Sysco facility, we utilize anhydrous ammonia which is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The properties which make ammonia valuable as a refrigerant also necessitate certain safety precautions.  Sysco strives to protect all its valuable resources and assets - both personnel and property.  We live and have families in this community.  We want to prevent exposure to all our personnel as well as nearby members of our community, natural resources, and the surrounding environment.  It is our policy to comply with all Federal, State, and Local regulations.  Through continual training and various safety devices and procedures, we work to minimize potential releases.
Our emergency response program has specific procedures for accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia as well as other emergencies.  We work in conjunction with the local Fire Department and the Hinds County Office of Emergency Management to prepare for necessary notification of all affected neighbors.

2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The primary purpose of our facility is the temporary storage and distribution of wholesale grocery items, some of which are refrigerated and/or frozen.  We utilize anhydrous ammonia as the primary means for refrigeration and freezing.  An outside company is used to fill our main receiver tank.  Piping then carries the ammonia to the needed cooling or freezing units.  Access to the site is restricted to facility employees, authorized management personnel, and authorized contractors.
The regulated substance used at our facility is anhydrous ammonia.  The maximum amount of ammonia stored at this facility is 12,752 pounds.  We have the capacity for more, but do not operate above 80% of total system capacity.

3.

THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario would be a release of 1,606 pounds of liquid ammonia from the main receiver. According to ALOHA models, this release would have a distance to end point of 1.5 miles in urban terrain.  According to the CAMEO and MARPLOT software, the affected area includes several commercial and industrial complexes, schools, churches, residences, and an airport.

4. THE ALTERNATIVE-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

The alternative-case release scenario would be a release of 122 pounds of gaseous ammonia from a relief valve located on the main receiver. According to ALOHA models, this release would have a distance to end point of 0.5 miles in urban terrain.  According to the CAMEO and MARPLOT software, the affected area includes several commercial and industrial complexes and also a few residences.

5. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

To date, this Sysco facility has only had one reportable release in the past.  This happened during the Christmas holidays in 2009.  A small oil line (1/4") on one of the compressors ruptured, allowing oil entrained with ammonia to escape into the engine room.  Once the concentration of ammonia reached a level of 150 parts per million (ppm), the ammonia detection system shut the system down and notified personnel.  It was estimated that the release was about 225-250 pounds of ammonia, over a period of 2-3 days.  There was no damage to the facility and no offsite damage was reported.  The oil line was repaired by a refrigeration contractor and the unit returned to service the following week.

6. THE RMP MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

The management of the RMP program will be handled by Byron Pitman.  Mr. Pitman will administrate in conjunction with the Sysco management and hourly personnel.  Other entities or organizations that will be coordinated with include the Jackson Fire Department, the HAZMAT team, and the Hinds County Office of Emergency Management.

7. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND TH

E SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

This Sysco facility complies with all applicable Federal, State, and Local regulations including EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule.  Our personnel are trained in this during our Hazard Communications Training and through access to our written programs.  Our refrigeration maintenance operators receive On-the-Job training as well as outside training courses such as the RETA Industrial Refrigeration Operators Courses, taught at Lanier Technical College in Oakwood, Georgia.  Operating personnel are also observed by senior maintenance personnel in order o demonstrate proper job skills and knowledge.  The ammonia system is operated, tested, and maintained to the standard of International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration, the most stringent standard of the ammonia industry.

8. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We work very closely with the Jackson Fire Department, HAZMAT team, and the Hinds County Office of Emergency Management for emergency preparedness.  We meet periodically with representatives of each to address any changes in the facility or any new concerns. 

Because of the limited amount of maintenance personnel on site, this Sysco facility does not respond to any large ammonia releases.  Our company policy dictates that in the event of a catastrophic ammonia release, all employees are evacuated to the appropriate assembly area and the local Fire Department and First Responders are notified.  Once on-site, the Fire Department and/or the First Responders coordinate with the appropriate Sysco personnel on what actions to take in order to minimize the effects of the release.

9. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Currently, Sysco trains and tests all refrigeration technicians.  Our preventative maintenance program is above standard.  Our ammonia Process Safety Management Program and our Risk Management Program is reviewed and updated annually (or as system modifications dictate).  Our programs are improved continuously through thes
e annual updates.  We also take advantage of new technologies when safer and more economical alternatives are available.
